"**We Gotta Get out of This Place** ", occasionally written "**We 've Gotta
Get out of This Place**",[1] is a rock song written by [Barry
Mann](/wiki/Barry_Mann "Barry Mann") and [Cynthia Weil](/wiki/Cynthia_Weil
"Cynthia Weil") and recorded as a 1965 hit single by [The
Animals](/wiki/The_Animals "The Animals"). It has become an iconic song of its
type and was immensely popular with [United States Armed
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces") GIs
during the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War").

In 2004 it was ranked number 233 on _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone
"Rolling Stone")_ 's [The 500 Greatest Songs of All
Time](/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "Rolling Stone's
500 Greatest Songs of All Time") list; it is also in [The Rock and Roll Hall
of Fame's 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and
Roll](/wiki/The_Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame%27s_500_Songs_that_Shaped_Rock_and_Roll
"The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll") list.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=We_Gotta_Get_out_of_This_Place&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil were husband and wife (and future [Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Songwriters_Hall_of_Fame "Songwriters Hall of Fame"))
[songwriters](/wiki/Songwriter "Songwriter") associated with the 1960s [Brill
Building](/wiki/Brill_Building "Brill Building") scene in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[2]

Mann and Weil wrote and recorded "We Gotta Get out of This Place" as a
[demo](/wiki/Demo_recording "Demo recording"), with Mann singing and playing
[piano](/wiki/Piano "Piano"). It was intended for [The Righteous
Brothers](/wiki/The_Righteous_Brothers "The Righteous Brothers"), for whom
they had written the number one hit "[You've Lost That Lovin'
Feelin'](/wiki/You%27ve_Lost_That_Lovin%27_Feelin%27 "You've Lost That Lovin'
Feelin'")"[3] but then Mann gained a recording contract for himself, and his
label [Red Bird Records](/wiki/Red_Bird_Records "Red Bird Records") wanted him
to release it instead. Meanwhile, record executive [Allen
Klein](/wiki/Allen_Klein "Allen Klein") had heard it and gave the demo to
[Mickie Most](/wiki/Mickie_Most "Mickie Most"), The Animals'
[producer](/wiki/Record_producer "Record producer"). Most already had a call
out to Brill Building songwriters for material for the group's next recording
session (The Animals hits "[It's My
Life](/wiki/It%27s_My_Life_\(The_Animals_song\) "It's My Life \(The Animals
song\)")" and "[Don't Bring Me
Down](/wiki/Don%27t_Bring_Me_Down_\(The_Animals_song\) "Don't Bring Me Down
\(The Animals song\)")" came from the same call[4]), and The Animals recorded
it before Mann could.[3]

In The Animals' rendition, the lyrics were slightly reordered and reworded
from the demo and opened with a locational allusion – although different from
that in the songwriters' minds – that was often taken as fitting the group's
[industrial](/wiki/Industrial_revolution "Industrial revolution"), [working
class](/wiki/Working_class "Working class") [Newcastle-upon-
Tyne](/wiki/Newcastle-upon-Tyne "Newcastle-upon-Tyne") origins:[5][6][7]

> In this dirty old part of the city  
>  Where the sun refused to shine  
>  People tell me, there ain't no use in tryin'

Next came a verse about the singer's father in his deathbed after a lifetime
of working his life away, followed by a call-and-response buildup, leading to
the start of the chorus:

> We gotta get out of this place!  
>  If it's the last thing we ever do…

The arrangement featured a distinctive bass lead by group member [Chas
Chandler](/wiki/Chas_Chandler "Chas Chandler").[8] This was the first single
not to be recorded by the original line-up, following as it did the departure
of keyboard player [Alan Price](/wiki/Alan_Price "Alan Price") and his
replacement by [Dave Rowberry](/wiki/Dave_Rowberry "Dave Rowberry"). It
featured one of singer [Eric Burdon](/wiki/Eric_Burdon "Eric Burdon")'s
typically raw, fierce vocals.[9][10] _Rolling Stone_ described the overall
effect as a "harsh white-blues treatment from The Animals. As [Burdon] put it,
'Whatever suited our attitude, we just bent to our own shape.'"[11]

The song reached number 2 on the [UK pop singles chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart
"UK Singles Chart") on August 14, 1965 (held out of the top slot by [The
Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")' "[Help!](/wiki/Help!_\(song\)
"Help! \(song\)")").[12] The following month, it reached number 13 on the
[U.S. pop singles chart](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"), its
highest placement there.[13] In Canada, the song also reached number 2, on
September 20, 1965.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### The two
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=We_Gotta_Get_out_of_This_Place&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: The two versions")]

The UK and US single releases were different versions from the same recording
sessions. The take that [EMI](/wiki/EMI "EMI"), The Animals' parent record
company, sent to [MGM Records](/wiki/MGM_Records "MGM Records"), the group's
American label, was mistakenly one that had not been selected for release
elsewhere. The two versions are most easily differentiated by the lyric at the
beginning of the second verse: in the US version the lyric is, "See my daddy
in bed a-dyin'", while the UK version uses, "Watch my daddy in bed a-dyin'"
(as a result of an error by the music labels, certain online retailers sell
the UK version but incorrectly identify it as the US version).

In the US the song (in its "mistaken" take) was included on the album _[Animal
Tracks](/wiki/Animal_Tracks_\(U.S._album\) "Animal Tracks \(U.S. album\)")_ ,
released in the fall 1965, and again on the popular compilation _[The Best of
The Animals](/wiki/The_Best_of_The_Animals_\(1966_album\) "The Best of The
Animals \(1966 album\)")_ released in 1966 and re-released with an expanded
track list on the [ABKCO](/wiki/ABKCO "ABKCO") label in 1973. The song was not
on any British Animals album during the group's lifetime.

Once Animals reissues began occurring during the [compact
disc](/wiki/Compact_disc "Compact disc") era, Allen Klein, by now owner of
[ABKCO](/wiki/ABKCO "ABKCO") and the rights to this material, dictated that
the "correct" British version be used on all reissues and compilations
everywhere. Thus, as US radio stations converted from vinyl records to CDs,
gradually only the British version became heard. Some collectors and fans in
the US wrote letters of complaint to _[Goldmine](/wiki/Goldmine_\(magazine\)
"Goldmine \(magazine\)")_ magazine, saying they believed the US version
featured an angrier and more powerful vocal from Burdon, and in any case
wanted to hear the song in the form they had grown up with. The 2004
remastered [SACD](/wiki/Super_Audio_CD "Super Audio CD") _Retrospective_
compilation from ABKCO included the US version.

##
Impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=We_Gotta_Get_out_of_This_Place&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Impact")]

At the time, the title and simple emotional appeal of "We Gotta Get out of
This Place" lent itself to some obvious self-identifications—for instance, it
was a very popular number to be played at high school [senior
proms](/wiki/Senior_prom "Senior prom") and graduation parties. In music
writer [Dave Marsh](/wiki/Dave_Marsh "Dave Marsh")'s view, it was one of a
wave of songs in 1965, by artists such as [The Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The
Beatles"), [The Rolling Stones](/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones "The Rolling
Stones"), and [Bob Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan"), that ushered in a new
role for rock music as a vehicle for common perception and as a force for
social consciousness.[14] Writer Craig Werner sees the song as reflecting the
desire of people to take a hard look at their own lives and the community they
come from.[10] Burdon later said, "The song became an anthem for different
people – everybody at some time wants to get out of the situation they're
in."[5]

The song was very popular with [United States Armed
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces") members
stationed in [South Vietnam](/wiki/South_Vietnam "South Vietnam") during the
[Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War").[7] It was frequently requested
of, and played by, [American Forces Vietnam
Network](/wiki/American_Forces_Vietnam_Network "American Forces Vietnam
Network") [disc jockeys](/wiki/Disc_jockey "Disc jockey").[15] During 2006 two
[University of
Wisconsin–Madison](/wiki/University_of_Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison "University
of Wisconsin–Madison") employees, one a Vietnam veteran, began an in-depth
survey of hundreds of Vietnam veterans, and found that "We Gotta Get out of
This Place" had resonated the strongest among all the music popular then: "We
had absolute unanimity is this song being the touchstone. This was the Vietnam
anthem. Every bad band that ever played in an armed forces club had to play
this song."[16] Just such a band played the song in an episode ("USO Down", by
Vietnam veteran [Jim Beaver](/wiki/Jim_Beaver "Jim Beaver")) of the American
television series about the war, _[Tour of
Duty](/wiki/Tour_of_Duty_\(TV_series\) "Tour of Duty \(TV series\)")_ , and
the song is reprised in the episode's final scene.

"We Gotta Get out of This Place" was also used in [Dennis
Potter](/wiki/Dennis_Potter "Dennis Potter")'s 1965 television play _[Stand
Up, Nigel Barton](/wiki/Stand_Up,_Nigel_Barton "Stand Up, Nigel Barton")_ and
the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC")'s 1996 [Newcastle](/wiki/Newcastle-upon-Tyne
"Newcastle-upon-Tyne")-set _[Our Friends in the
North](/wiki/Our_Friends_in_the_North "Our Friends in the North")_ , which
partially took place in the 1960s. In America it was used as the title credits
song in some episodes of the Vietnam War-set television series _[China
Beach](/wiki/China_Beach "China Beach")_. It was then applied to the Bin Laden
family, having to leave the United States in the aftermath of the [September
11th terrorist attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"), in
[Michael Moore](/wiki/Michael_Moore "Michael Moore")'s 2004 _[Fahrenheit
9/11](/wiki/Fahrenheit_9/11 "Fahrenheit 9/11")_. It also was featured in the
soundtrack to the 1987 movie _[Hamburger Hill](/wiki/Hamburger_Hill "Hamburger
Hill")_. It was used in a third-season episode of the 2000s television series
_[Heroes](/wiki/Heroes_TV_series "Heroes TV series")_. It was used as the
theme song for 2002 BBC comedy _[TLC](/wiki/TLC_\(TV_series\) "TLC \(TV
series\)")_ and the 2013 BBC series _[Privates](/wiki/Privates_\(TV_series\)
"Privates \(TV series\)")_. The song was also featured humorously in the
_[Kong: Skull Island](/wiki/Kong:_Skull_Island "Kong: Skull Island")_
trailer[17]

In a 2012 keynote speech to an audience at the [South by
Southwest](/wiki/South_by_Southwest "South by Southwest") music festival,
[Bruce Springsteen](/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen "Bruce Springsteen") performed an
abbreviated version of The Animals' version on acoustic guitar and then said,
"That's every song I've ever written. That's all of them. I'm not kidding,
either. That’s '[Born to Run](/wiki/Born_to_Run_\(song\) "Born to Run
\(song\)")', '[Born in the U.S.A.](/wiki/Born_in_the_U.S.A._\(song\) "Born in
the U.S.A. \(song\)")'"[18]

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=We_Gotta_Get_out_of_This_Place&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: In popular culture")]

The song's title and theme have become a common cultural phrase over the
years.

It formed the basis for the title of academician [Lawrence
Grossberg](/wiki/Lawrence_Grossberg "Lawrence Grossberg")'s _[We Gotta Get out
of This Place: Popular Conservatism and Postmodern Culture
(1992)](/wiki/We_Gotta_Get_out_of_This_Place:_Popular_Conservatism_and_Postmodern_Culture_\(1992\)
"We Gotta Get out of This Place: Popular Conservatism and Postmodern Culture
\(1992\)")_ , detailing the conflict between [American
conservatism](/wiki/American_conservatism "American conservatism") and rock
culture. Similarly, it formed the title basis for Gerri Hirshey's 2002
account, _We Gotta Get out of This Place: The True, Tough Story of Women in
Rock_.

It has also been used as the title of editorials by _[American Journalism
Review](/wiki/American_Journalism_Review "American Journalism Review")_[19]
and other publications. The title was even used to name an art exhibit,
curated by Stefan Kalmar at the Cubitt Gallery in [London](/wiki/London
"London") in 1997.

## The Angels
version[[edit](/w/index.php?title=We_Gotta_Get_out_of_This_Place&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: The Angels version")]

We Gotta Get Out of This Place is the twenty eighth single by Australian [Hard
rock](/wiki/Hard_rock "Hard rock") band [The
Angels](/wiki/The_Angels_\(Australian_band\) "The Angels \(Australian
band\)"), released in 1986.[20][21] It is the third single to be released from
The Angels eighth studio album [Howling](/wiki/Howling_\(The_Angels_album\)
"Howling \(The Angels album\)"). The song peaked at number 7 on the [ARIA
Charts](/wiki/ARIA_Charts "ARIA Charts") and number 13 on the [Recorded Music
NZ](/wiki/Recorded_Music_NZ "Recorded Music NZ"),[22][23]

## Other
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=We_Gotta_Get_out_of_This_Place&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Other versions")]

"We Gotta Get out of This Place" has been recorded or performed in concert by
numerous artists, including [The Cryan' Shames](/wiki/The_Cryan%27_Shames "The
Cryan' Shames") (1966), [The American Breed](/wiki/The_American_Breed "The
American Breed") (1967), [The Frost](/wiki/The_Frost "The Frost") (1970), [The
Partridge Family](/wiki/The_Partridge_Family "The Partridge Family") (1972),
[Bruce Springsteen](/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen "Bruce Springsteen") (performed
only a handful of times in his career, but acknowledged by him as one of his
primary influences in the 1970s[24]), [Udo Lindenberg](/wiki/Udo_Lindenberg
"Udo Lindenberg") (in a German language adaption in the 1970s for which
commercial success was small), [Blue Öyster Cult](/wiki/Blue_%C3%96yster_Cult
"Blue Öyster Cult") (1978), [Steve Bender](/wiki/Dschinghis_Khan "Dschinghis
Khan") (1978), [Gilla](/wiki/Gilla_\(singer\) "Gilla \(singer\)") (1979),
[Angelic Upstarts](/wiki/Angelic_Upstarts "Angelic Upstarts") (1980), [Gardens
& Villa](/wiki/Gardens_%26_Villa "Gardens & Villa"), [Grand Funk
Railroad](/wiki/Grand_Funk_Railroad "Grand Funk Railroad") (1981), [David
Johansen](/wiki/David_Johansen "David Johansen") (1982, and a hit on [album
oriented rock](/wiki/Album_oriented_rock "Album oriented rock") radio and
[MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") as part of an Animals medley),
[Fear](/wiki/Fear_\(band\) "Fear \(band\)") (1982), [The
Angels](/wiki/The_Angels_\(Australian_band\) "The Angels \(Australian band\)")
(1986), [Richard Thompson](/wiki/Richard_Thompson_\(musician\) "Richard
Thompson \(musician\)") (1988), [Jello Biafra](/wiki/Jello_Biafra "Jello
Biafra") and [D.O.A.](/wiki/D.O.A._\(band\) "D.O.A. \(band\)") (1989), [Randy
Stonehill](/wiki/Randy_Stonehill "Randy Stonehill") (1990), [Bon
Jovi](/wiki/Bon_Jovi "Bon Jovi") (1992, again as part of an Animals medley for
an MTV special), [Midnight Oil](/wiki/Midnight_Oil "Midnight Oil") (1993, for
_[MTV Unplugged](/wiki/MTV_Unplugged "MTV Unplugged")_),
[Space](/wiki/Space_\(indie_rock_band\) "Space \(indie rock band\)") (1998),
[Southside Johnny](/wiki/Southside_Johnny "Southside Johnny") (concerts in the
2000s), Overkill (2000), [Widespread Panic](/wiki/Widespread_Panic "Widespread
Panic") (2005), [Ann Wilson](/wiki/Ann_Wilson "Ann Wilson") with [Wynonna
Judd](/wiki/Wynonna_Judd "Wynonna Judd") (2007), [Alice
Cooper](/wiki/Alice_Cooper "Alice Cooper") (2011), and many others.

In 1990 Eric Burdon joined [Katrina and the Waves](/wiki/Katrina_and_the_Waves
"Katrina and the Waves") for a recording of it for use on _China Beach_. In
2000 Barry Mann revisited the song, performing it with [Bryan
Adams](/wiki/Bryan_Adams "Bryan Adams") on Mann's retrospective solo album
_Soul & Inspiration_. When [Suzi Quatro](/wiki/Suzi_Quatro "Suzi Quatro") was
on a German tour in 2008 she came on stage and played bass on the song during
an Eric Burdon concert at the [Porsche Arena](/wiki/Porsche_Arena "Porsche
Arena") in [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart"). Burdon also performed it
in 2010 at the [Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Induction
Ceremony](/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame_Induction_Ceremony "Rock and Roll
Hall of Fame Induction Ceremony"), when songwriters Mann and Weil were
inducted.[25] Later in 2010, Mann and Weil were at [The Grammy
Museum](/wiki/The_Grammy_Museum "The Grammy Museum") in [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") – to open a gallery for the
[Songwriter's Hall of Fame](/wiki/Songwriter%27s_Hall_of_Fame "Songwriter's
Hall of Fame")[26] – and performed their original version of the song,
including previously-unheard lyrics like "What are we waiting for?" (which was
supposed to occur before the familiar lyrics in the chorus).
